708751f-a.text:
Fifth Avenue at the N.W. corner of 42nd Street, when site was
occupied by the Henry A. Siebrecht green-house.
At a later period the Bristol Hotel was erected on this site. As business interests advanced in the mid-town section, the Bristol Hotel was converted into an office building. It was demolished in 1929, to make way for the Fifth Avenue Building,
1875

708797f-a.text:
Fifth Avenue, north from 42nd Street.
Temple Emanu-El at right. The other churches whose spires are seen are still standing (1933) except St. Thomas's ProtestantEpiscopal Church, the third spire on the left, which burned and was replaced by the present edifice.
1894

Brown Brothers, Photographers.
Slide #37

708784f-a.text:
Fifth Avenue, east side, from East 42nd to 43rd Streets, as viewed from a vantage point in front of the old reservoir. Note the horse-drawn coach southward bound. To the left is Temple Emanu-El, a synagogue replaced in 1927 by the towering Lefcourt National Building. This is at the N. E. corner of East 43rd Street. All of these structures are gone in 1940 with the exception of the building bearing the signs.
1898-9

708793f-a.text:
Fifth Avenue, north from a point slightly to the south of 42nd Street, showing a procession of electric cabs and their earlier prototypes, the horse drawn hansom, silhouetted against buildings on the east
side of this thoroughfare.
The photographers vantage point is in front of the old reservoir, now the site of the New York Public Library.
To the left of center is the twin towered synagogue, Emanu-El. The uncompleted office structure at the S.E. corner of 45th Street was finished in 1899 and thereby dates this photo. Beyond are the spires of St. Patrick, St. Thomas, and St. Nicholas Churchs.
1898-9

708800f-a.text:
5th Ave. n from 42nd St.

P.L. Sperr collection (crossed out)
Rec'd January 13, 1945 (crossed out)

Copyright 1899 by J.S. Johnston N.Y.
Slide #'s 11. Neg. #2666

708678f-a.text:
Fifth Avenue, west side, south from 42nd Street, showing the old reservoir occupying the avenue frontage. Upon this site was erected the present New York Public Library Building.
At the left is the spire atop the Brick Presbytertan Church silhouetted against the old Waldrof Astoria Hotel. To the right, at the rear of the reservoir is Bryant Park extending to Sixth Avenue. The hazy outline beyond is the Jersey shore.
1900
From C. Davis Plate Picture Collection

708790f-a.text:
Fifth Avenue, north from 42nd Street, as photographed from a vantage point at the S. E. corner. Under construction at the left is the building at the S. W. corner of 43rd Street. In the background appears the spire of the Collegiate Church of St. Nicholas outlined
against the Heckscher (?) Building.
About 1900's
Thomas W. Kennedy, photo
Thru Beecher Ogden
Museum Photo. Assn.

713026f-a.text:
West 42nd Street, north side, between Fifth and Sixth Avenue's, showing the West Presbyterian Church. It was organized in 1829 with 18 members and its first house of worship was erected on Carmine Street in 1832. The structure shown was erected in 1862.
Note the Single Tax Club in the adjoining building at No. 27. The date of this photo is inferred from the presence of the electrified street car tracks.
About 1905
Gift of Urbrock Collection

708792f.text:
Fifth Avenue, north across 42nd Street, showing mainly the easterly side of this arterial thoroughfare as photographed from in front of the Reservoir. In the center, at the N.E corner of 43rd Street is the Temple Emanu-El. The spire of St. Patrick's Cathedral appears in the background.
About 1905
Gift of Urbrock Collection
Neg.#2186

708794f-a.text:
Fifth Avenue, north from 42nd Street, showing traffic conditions on this main arterial thoroughfare at an early date. In the foreground, at the N.E. corner of the Avenue and East 43rd Street, is the original Temple Beth-El which subsequent1y moved uptown. Outlined in the distance are the spires of St. Patricks Cathedral opposite that atop the Collegiate Church of St. Nicholas. On the left is the old Bennett Bldg. which stood for years at the N.W. corner of Fifth Avenue and W. 42nd Street. The row of 5-story brownstones bearing advertising material will provide a site for the subsequent Postal Life Insurance Co. Bldg. The interesting point in reference to this is that the corner
building was the home of "Boss" Tweed.
This photostat is one of a set depicting traffic conditions and filed under Police Activities and various Fifth Avenue locations and are evidently part of a group published in the March 11, 1909
issue - page 229.
About 1909
Lealiea Weekly
Copyright-Judge Co.
Ho Reproductions.
Slide#148

708795f-a.text:
North on Fifth Avenue from S. W. corner of 42nd Street, showing early type of Fifth Avenue motor-drawn bus, Bristol Building, formerly Bristol Hotel, at left foreground.
Temple Emanu-El at right centre.
1912.
Ewing Galloway, Photographer.

1557924.title: Fifth Avenue - West 42nd Street
1557924.folder: Fifth Avenue - West 42nd Street, Manhattan, NY

712987f-a.text:
East 42nd Street, north side, east from Fifth Ave., showing construction work in progress on Grand Central Station, Vanderbilt Ave., to Depew Place (no longer in existence). Grand Central station was opened in 1913 and is the terminal for the new York Central Railroad, and the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad-

Prior to 1913.

Ewing Galloway.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.

713031f-b.text:
(1) West 42nd Street, west from a point slightly west of Fifth Ave. and showing buildings on the north side facing Bryant Park. Prominent building shown in the background is the Bush Terminal Building. Note its 8-story annex under construction. The left foreground of this view is the base of the huge Salmon Tower Building.

1916.

Nicholas Savostayanoff.
Gift of Geo. D. Chinn.

(2) A detail of the buildings seen in No. 1 and showing mainly the 18-story Aeolian Hall Building, No. 29-33 West 42nd Street, as viewed in a northward direction,from the Bryant Park Mall at the rear of the New York Public Library (right). To the right of the Hall appears the 5 storied Central Building; while to the left is Stern Brothers Department Store.

1916.

Nicholas Savostayanoff.
Gift of Geo. D. Chinn.

713031f-a.text:
(1) West 42nd Street, west from a point slightly west of Fifth Ave. and showing buildings on the north side facing Bryant Park. Prominent building shown in the background is the Bush Terminal Building. Note its 8-story annex under construction. The left foreground of this view is the base of the huge Salmon Tower Building.

1916.

Nicholas Savostayanoff.
Gift of Geo. D. Chinn.

(2) A detail of the buildings seen in No. 1 and showing mainly the 18-story Aeolian Hall Building, No. 29-33 West 42nd Street, as viewed in a northward direction,from the Bryant Park Mall at the rear of the New York Public Library (right). To the right of the Hall appears the 5 storied Central Building; while to the left is Stern Brothers Department Store.

1916.

Nicholas Savostayanoff.
Gift of Geo. D. Chinn.

1557923.title: Fifth Avenue - West 42nd Street
1557923.folder: Fifth Avenue - West 42nd Street, Manhattan, NY

708802f-a.text:
New York's Fifth Avenue -- the Avenue of the Allies
During the entire Liberty Loan Campaign in New York this famous street was decorated as never before. Each of the Allied nations, from Great Britain, to Siam and Liberia, had a block set apart in its special honor.
The Avenue is shown from 42nd Street looking north.
Oct. 1918
Underwood and Underwood
Neg. #3166

713033f-a.text:
42nd Street, north side, west from and including the new Aeolian Hall, 29-33 West 42nd Street between Fifth and Sixth Avenues.
1921.
Neg. #3246

708759f-a.text:
Fifth Ave., at and adjoining the S.E. corner of East 42nd Street. Shown on the corner directly, is the Bankers Trust Building (Nos. 495-501). This view is as seen across the plaza at the front of the New York Public Library.
About 1920.
Gift of E. M. Jenks.
Neg. #1997

1557920.title: Fifth Avenue - West 42nd Street
1557920.folder: Fifth Avenue - West 42nd Street, Manhattan, NY

712992f-a.text:
42nd Street, south side, Public Library and Bryant Park, west
from Fifth Avenue.
Probably 1927.
Ewing Galloway.
Neg: 3112

713017f-a.text:
West 42nd Street, at, adjoining and west (right to left) of the N.W. corner of Fifth Ave., showing the site of the present skyscraper, No. 500 Fifth Ave., prior to clearance. This consisted of the Bristol Building (No. 500 Fifth Ave.) at the corner and 4 five story structures that bore Nos. 3 to 9 West 42nd Street, inclusive.
December 4, 1929.
Irving Underhill.

713016f-a.text:
West 42nd Street, at the N.W. corner of Fifth Ave. Shown at the
corner proper, is the Bristol Building.
August 15, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.

713002f-a.text:
42nd Street, at Fifth Ave., as seen from the Republican Club (54-56 West 4Oth Street) and across Bryant Park. Shown from left to right are, Stern Bros, Aeolian Hall Building (under renovations), Salmon Tower (newly completed), No's 9 to 3 West 42nd Street inclusive (5-story brownstones), and the Bristol Building (N.W. corner of Fifth Ave.); the last two items have been replaced by the building called No. 500 Fifth Ave. The rear of the New York Public Library is shown at the eastern side of Bryant Park; the front of which is on the west side of Fifth Ave. This building extends from 4Oth to 42nd Streets. Notice the absence of skyscrapers which appear in this area today.
About 1928.
Ewing Galloway.

712990f-a.text:
42nd Street, south side, east from Fifth Avenue.
August, 1929.
Ewing Galloway.

713003f-a.text:
42nd Street at Fifth Ave. The same as mount No. 1, showing on the
right a view eastward on 40th Street.
About 1928.
Ewing Galloway.
Neg # 2085

708765f-a.text:
Demolishing Hotel Bristol, Fifth Avenue at N.W. corner of 42nd Street.

December 16, 1929.

Irving Underhill, Photographer.

708766f-a.text:
Demolishing Bristol Hotel, Fifth avenue at N.W. corner of 42nd Street, to make way for 500 Fifth Avenue Building.
December 16, 1929.
Irving Underhill, Photographer.

708763f-a.text:
Demolishing Bristol Hotel, Fifth Avenue at N.W. corner of 42nd
Street, from Public Library.
December 4, 1929.

708764f-a.text:
Demolition of Bristol Hotel, N.W. corner of Fifth Avenue at 42nd Street, from 42nd Street entrance to Public Library.
December 4, 1929.
Irving Underhill, Photographer.

1557918.title: Fifth Avenue - West 42nd Street
1557918.folder: Fifth Avenue - West 42nd Street, Manhattan, NY

717920f-a.text:
Bryant Park, north section, eastward along West 42nd Street. Buildings shown are on the north side of West 42nd Street, east from Sixth to Fifth Aves. Note the structual work at the N.W. corner of Fifth Ave. This will be the skyscraper, No. 500 Fifth Ave. when completed. Views 2 and 3 show a portion of the rear of the New York Public Library which faces on the Ave. Also note in these, the uncompleted spire of the
Chrysler Building.
May 10, 1930.
P. L. Sperr.

717920f-c.text:
Bryant Park, north section, eastward along West 42nd Street. Buildings shown are on the north side of West 42nd Street, east from Sixth to Fifth Aves. Note the structual work at the N.W. corner of Fifth Ave. This will be the skyscraper, No. 500 Fifth Ave. when completed. Views 2 and 3 show a portion of the rear of the New York Public Library which faces on the Ave. Also note in these, the uncompleted spire of the
Chrysler Building.
May 10, 1930.
P. L. Sperr.

717920f-b.text:
Bryant Park, north section, eastward along West 42nd Street. Buildings shown are on the north side of West 42nd Street, east from Sixth to Fifth Aves. Views 2 and 3 show a portion of the rear of the New York Public Library which faces on the Ave. Also note in these, the uncompleted spire of the
Chrysler Building.
May 10, 1930.
P. L. Sperr.

Start of construction work on 500 Fifth Avenue Building, at N.W.
corner of 42nd Street.

708773f-a.text:
500 Fifth Avenue Building at 42nd Street, about half completed. Taken from S.E. corner of Fifth Avenue at 42nd Street.

708774f-a.text:
500 Fifth Avenue Building at N.W. corner of 42nd Street, nearly
completed.
Taken from S.E. Corner of Fifth Avenue and 42nd Street.

708775f-a.text:
500 Fifth Avenue Building at N.W. corner of 42nd Street, nearing completion.
October 1, 1930.

708776f-a.text:
500 Fifth Avenue Building nearing completion. Taken from S.E.
corner of Fifth Avenue and 42nd Street.
October 1, 1930.

708777f.text:
South on Fifth Avenue from 43rd Street, showing 500 Fifth Avenue. Building nearly completed.
Note construction work on Empire State Building in background.
October 1, 1930.
Irving Underhill, Photographer.

708778f-a.text:
Removing scaffolding from tower of 500 Fifth Avenue Building, at N.W. corner of 42nd Street.
December 1, 1930.
Irving Underhill, Photographer.

708769f-a.text:
Clearing for erection of 500 Fifth Avenue Building, at N.W. corner of 42nd Street.
January 16, 1930.
Irving Vnderhill, Photographer.

The building of 500 5th Avenue, at north west corner 5th Avenue and 42nd Street.
Date: Feb. 1, 1930.

The building of 500 Fifth Avenue, at north west corner 5th Avenue and 42nd Street.
Date: May 1, 1930.

708768f-a.text:
Demolishing Bristol Hotel, N.W. corner of Fifth Avenue at 42nd Street, from steps of Public Library.
January 2, 1930.
Irving Underhill, Photographer.

June 24, 1931.

712985f-a.text:
2-60 East 42nd Street, between Fifth and Park Avenues, sn serial view from 500 Fifth Avenue.

June 24, 1931

712991f-a.text:
East 42nd Street, north side, east from and including Fifth Ave., showing (left) under construction the 58-story building, No. 500 Fifth Ave., at the N.W. corner of West 42nd Street. In the background is visible the Chrysler Building, on the east side of Lexington Ave. from East 42nd to East 43rd Streets.
About 1930.
Ewing Galloway
NEG. 4385

708856f-a.text:
North on Fifth Avenue, from No. 500 at N. W. corner of 42nd Street.
June 24, 1931.

730185f-a.text:
A general view, east from 500 Fifth Ave., at the N.W. corner of 42nd Street, showing in the centre the Hotel Biltmore (Vanderbilt Ave., and 43rd St)., and to the right of the hotel, the Grand Central Terminal Building 42nd Street, between Vanderbilt and Lexington Aves.
June 24, 1931.
P. L. Sperr.

730178f-a.text:
A general view, northeast from 500 Fifth Ave., N.W. corner of 42nd Street, showing in the centre the Grand Central Building, (45th St., between Vanderbilt and Lexington Aves). A view of the East River is also shown in the background.
June 24, 1931.

of the point of vantage.

712989f-a.text:
42nd Street side of the Seymour Building, at the N.E. corner of Fifth Avenue.
May 15, 1932.
P. L. Sperr.

717904f-a.text:
Bryant Park, eastern and southern portions, seen from the roof of 500 Fifth Avenue at 42nd Street, and depicting an early spring snowfall, the day following Palm Sunday.
In the right center, west of the fountain, the foundations for the Federal Hall replica, a part of the George Washington Bicentennial Celebration. The snow-covered roof of the New York Public Library is shown in the left foreground.
March 21, 1932.
International News Photos, Inc.
Neg: #2754

733309f-a.title: Street scenes - Miscellaneous.
733309f-a.text:
Street Scene, Miscellaneous: Salvation Army workers on West 42nd Street between Fifth and Sixth Aves. In the background appears the rear
of the New York Public Library and Bryant Park.
December 24, 1935.
P. L. Sperr.

712993f-a.text:
42nd Street, north side, east from and including Fifth Ave. The light colored building on the left, is known as 500 Fifth Ave; the Public Library is on the right. The Chrysler Building in the background (at the N.E. corner of Lexington Ave)., overshadows the Hotel Commodore.
1936.
New York Public Library.

717908f-a.text:
Bryant Park: A noon hour diversion; feeding the pigeons in the park. This view taken in the N.W. corner, shows West 42nd Street in the background.
Fall 1936.
Gift of Geo. D. Chinn.

730280f.title: General view - [Manhattan - 42nd Street (East) - Lincoln Building (Northeast) ; 60 East 42nd Street - Vanderbilt Avenue ; General Electric Company ; Grand Central Building ; New York Hospital ; Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.]
730280f.text:
60 E. 42nd Street, (Lincoln Building) south side, west of Pershing Square (general view northeastward). Merging on the left are the Grand Central Building, the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria and the General Electric Building. Numerous Sutton Place apartment structures are nestled on the right at the Queensboro Bridge approach. Beyond same is the white pile of the N. Y. Hospital-Cornell Medical College. The East River, Welfare Island, Long Island City and the blended Triborough and Hellgate Bridges are easily identifiable.
1937-8
Alexander Alland
This photo is one of a series that appeared in the published volume "Portrait of N. Y." by Felix Reisenberg and Alex. Alland, IRGV.

712999f-a.text:
(1)
West 42nd Street, at Fifth Ave., as seen from the rear of the New York Public Library (right), and showing the upper reaches of No. 500 Fifth Ave., a skyscraper at the N.W. corner of 42nd Street. Building shown on the left, is the Salmon Towers and it adjoins its taller sister on 42nd Street.
March 1937.
Gift of Mary Nelle Griffith.
(2)
The original of No. 1, which is an enlargement.
March 27, 1937.
Gift of Mary Nelle Griffith.

712999f-b.text:
(1)
West 42nd Street, at Fifth Ave., as seen from the rear of the New York Public Library (right), and showing the upper reaches of No. 500 Fifth Ave., a skyscraper at the N.W. corner of 42nd Street. Building shown on the left, is the Salmon Towers and it adjoins its taller sister on 42nd Street.
March 1937.

713019f-a.text:
West 42nd Street, at the N.W. corner of Fifth Ave., showing the site cleared for the skyscraper, No. 500 Fifth Ave. The 4-story building, adjoining the clearance, and whose side wall is exposed, is No. 508. North of same, at the S.W. corner of West 43rd Street is the 8-story Ziegler Building, No. 510-14. Appearing on the right are three buildings, Nos. 513-11, 509 and 507; the 10-story Postal Life being the first and located at the S.W. corner of East 43rd Street.
January 16, 1930.
Irving Underhill.

713023f-a.text:
West 42nd Street, at, adjoining and west of the N.W. corner of Fifth Ave., showing the new Salmon Tower Building, that replaced Nos. 11 to 27. The low buildings on the right are the Bristol Building (500 Fifth Ave.) and four 5-story structures (Nos. 3 to 9) that have today been replaced
by the towering skysoraper, No. 500 Fifth Ave.
1929.
American Photo Service.

713029f-a.text:
West 42nd Street, west from a point between Fifth and Sixth Avenue's, showing a crosstown street car outlined against the buildings on the north side of the street. In the background is a station of the old Sixth Avenue Elevated Line.
1889
H. N. Tiemann, photo
Gift of Urbrock Collection
Neg # 2219

712988f-b.text:
(1)
42nd Street, south side, east from and including Fifth Avenue, during the Silver Jubilee parade commemorating the twenty-fifth Anniversary of the Greater City of New York.
Summer, 1923.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
The same, the following year.
1924.
P. L. Sperr.

712988f-a.text:
(1)

713001f-a.text:
42nd St. bet. 5th & 6th Aves.

...................New York City
42nd St., looking over Bryant Park. The prominent buildings, reading from left to right (West to East) are: Stern Bros. Department Store, old Aeolian Hall, Salmon Tower Building, and across the street the Lincoln Building under construction. A section of the N.Y. Public Library is seen in right hand corner.

713015f-a.text:
(1)
1, 3-9, 11 West 42nd Street, at and adjoining the N.W. corner
of Fifth Ave.
August 15, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.

1905.

708756f-a.text:
Fifth Avenue, east side, south from 42nd Street, showing at extreme right New York Public Library.
September 28, 1928.
New York Edison Company Collection.

708755f.text:
501-495 Fifth Ave., at the S.E. corner of East 42nd Street, showing a 7-story building, erected in 1910, under demolition. Upon this site will rise the 21-story Bankers Trust Co. Building. This set consists of a negative and a positive.
Between 1916 and 1922.
F. M. Demarest.
Gift of Albert A. Volk Co.

708757f-a.text:
501-495 Fifth Ave., at the S.E. corner of East 42nd Street, showing the demolition of a 7-story structure. Upon this site was constructed a new 7-story affair; the latter in turn being demolished prior to 1922 and replaced by the present (1937) 21-story Bankers Trust Co. Building.
This set consists of a negative and a positive.
June 24, 1910.
A. Drummond.
Gift of Albert A. Volk Co.

708757f-b.text:
501-495 Fifth Ave., at the S.E. corner of East 42nd Street, showing the demolition of a 7-story structure. Upon this site was constructed a new 7-story affair; the latter in turn being demolished prior to 1922 and replaced by the present (1937) 21-story Bankers Trust Co. Building.
This set consists of a negative and a positive.
June 24, 1910.
A. Drummond.

708758f.text:
5O1-495 and 491-487 Fifth Ave. (foreground) at and adjoining the S.E. corner of East 42nd Street (left) and showing the site for the new 21-story Bankers Trust Co. Building (No. 501-495) being cleared. In addition, this view includes Nos. 12 to 26 East 42nd Street (left); a row of narrow frontage edifices, located on the south side, between Fifth and Madison Aves. This set consists of a negative and a positive.
Between 1916 and 1922.
F. M. Demarest.
Gift of Albert A. Volk Co.

708753f.text:
Fifth Avenue, at 42nd Street, as photographed from the 45th floor of the skyscraper (No. 500 Fifth Avenue) at the N.W. corner. The street cars are on 42nd St. At the upper right hand corner is the plaza in front of the New York Public Library.
September 15, 1940
Robert A. Knudtsen
221 E. 31st St., N.Y.C.

708798f-a.text:
Fifth Ave., east side, north from but not including East 42nd Street, showing Temple Emanuel, at the N.E. corner of East 43rd Street. The temple was demolished sometime between 1925 and 193O and on its site was erected the 40-story structure, Lefcourt-National Building. The congregation of Temple Emanuel erected a new house of prayer on Fifth Ave., at the N.E. corner of East 65th Street. The congregation consists of the upper social strata of New York Jewry and services are conducted in English.
Prior to 1925.

731265f-a.title: Celebrations - Parades - Municipal events - N. R. A. [National Recovery Administration] Day.

September 13, 1933.

731266f-a.title: Celebrations - Parades - Municipal events - N. R. A. [National Recovery Administration] Parade.
731266f-a.text:
Celebration Parades:
N.R.A. Parade in New York: General View of the Mighty Demonstration for the N.R.A. given in New York September 13, when more than 250,000 Paraded up Fifth Avenue. It was the biggest Demonstration which Gotham has seen since War times. This blew is looding south on fifth Avenue from 42nd Street, with the reviewing stand and part of the public library at right. In the Background is the Empire State building. There were more than a million spectators along the line of March.

Associated Press Studio                                                            October 13, 1933.
